MikeSmith: For running tests, the W3C really should standardize on a handful of sane test runners appropriate for each test type. We've imported a large number of tests from others, modifying 19 different test frameworks to talk to our central test systems.

The different JS test frameworks aren't _that_ different from each other, though. I'm more concerned about testing stuff that ordinarly would require some soft of user interaction. At Opera, we use the Watir API for such tests. We have about 500-600 tests of HTML form interaction, for example. That would be good to share.

hmm, microsyntax for valid e-mail address changing…
I think the v.nu checker for e-mail addresses was not up to date with spec anyway
not a high priority change anyway
i was tempted to reject it in fact
in other news, we do have support for checking dropzone now
and the way it's implemented is a good example of tradeoffs between trying to have something useful in the base relaxng schema, along with additional (Java) code for checking other constraints
cool
in this case, the schema handles checking whether it the individual keywords are valid -- exactly one of copy, move, link and then any number of  f:.* and/or s.*
and the Java code handles checking whether there are any duplicates for any of the f: or s: keywords
but
fancy schema
it could be implemented by adding a specific "datazone" datatype to the v.nu HTML datatype library, and putting all the checking in that
the advantage of that would be better error reporting
because then we get fine-grained control of the text of the error messages
s/datazone/dropzone/
anyway, whereas with putting checks in the schema, we get more generic error messages that are less helpful to users in, e.g.,  pinpointing which keyword in the dropzone value is the offending one
I guess there has been a progression in v.nu away from doing checks in the schema just because they can be
and instead moving them into the Java code where we have more control and can emit better error messages
I think for users of the different parts, it will end up as sort of a case of progressive enhancement
or graceful degradation

in that, if somebody wants to use the schema by itself, without the datatype library -- e.g., for use in a context-sensitive editor -- then they can't expect us to optimize the schema for that use case
in fact, we and they are really better off if somebody produces a different schema that is optimized for that use case
which is what we will have eventually, I'm sure

I don't care the name. I just want a standard way to detect the new capabilities on HTML. Will be there one?
artenix: http://diveintohtml5.org/detect.html
zcorpan tnx. So, use Modernizr lib uh?
yeah

Because now HTML is a living spec, I think the smartest thing is providing a well-designed and standard capability detection method. The soup http://diveintohtml5.org/detect.html will be a nightmare to use as HTML evolves
Those with strong opinions about it weren't there when the canvas was empty.
Don't get me wrong, I am more than happy with WHATWG. I just want to see fixed the incompatability problems on HTML once and for all
artenix: what's wrong with the current detection mechanisms?
I don't enjoy using CSS hacks :)
you don't need css hacks to detect html5 features
artenix: fixing incompatibility problems is a large part of what whatwg is doing
zcorpan "call a method and see the return value" , "Set a property to a certain value, then check if the property has retained its value." C'mon! Is the best we can do?
"Use a JS lib somebody maintains... and hope she will be maintaining it in the years to come"
artenix: it's the most reliable we can do, yeah. http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-xml/2011Jan/0231.html
No sir, IMHO HTML needs a *standard* way to detect capabilities.
zcorpan lemme
zcorpan lemme read the lastima
s/ima//

artenix: there is a standard way to detect capabilities. you just look at what the feature you want to test actually is, and then see if it's there or not. e.g. for web sockets, it's a constructor called "WebSocket" exposed on window, so the detection is if ('WebSocket' in window)
Zcorpan and for <video> is different.

artenix: something like hasFeature has great problems with dividing up features you'd want to detect, not considering implementation bugs, and has a history of being completely unreliable and hence useless for its intended purpose
"Having something like DOM's hasFeature detect for larger sets of features doesn't work on the Web." I think more on testing SMALL set of features (or just 1)
what's "a small set of features" or "just one feature"?
I meant, hasFeature should test 1 small tiny specific on behaivor and semantic feature.
That way, $IMPORTANT_SITE could test for the fragores it really needs

problem with that is that it's a major undertaking to divide all the web platform's features into hasFeature strings and maintaining them and implementing them, which takes time away from implementing new features and fixing bugs in existing features
and i'm not convinced that it would STILL be reliable to actually be useful
s/fragores/features/  iPhone autocomplete needs debugging :)
the feature detection Modernizr uses comes for free when a browser implements the feature, which is good in two ways: it's reliable, and it doesn't cost anything

Look. I speak as a Web developer here. I need a reliable way to use the new exciting tags and technolgy associated with HTML(5) , while providing the simplest experience for users using older browsers.
Is WHATWG addresing that?
artenix: yeah. it's just that the feature detection method isn't as clean as you'd like
artenix: if we've tried to make the detection method clean and reliable, then that would take away time for bugfixing and new features
artenix: since there already is a reliable way to detect features, we'd rather spend time on fixing bugs and implementing new features

Ok. I can live with a "dirty" detection methods. But only if the browsers implementators agree on which dirtiness to use. I don't want to have to use one method for IE, another for FF, other for Opera, Safari, etc etc
deal :)

re-posted from #html5: sorry if this question has been asked and answered a ton already, but given that HTML5 is now just HTML, are efforts in promoting and branding the newer features in browsers as "HTML5" going to continue?
(or is that not really a big concern of this channel/group?)
danbeam: It seems highly likely that people will continue to use html5 as a marketing term
jgraham: I agree this is likely.  Perhaps I'm being pedantic, but aren't they're basically promoting a non-existent specification if they continue "repping" HTML5?
aren't they*
danbeam: w3c still calls its spec "HTML5"
(though I guess there is a snapshot of a semi-formed "HTML 5" specification, right?)
danbeam: It helps if you think of "HTML5 as being 'The group of technologies that make up the Open Web Platform c. 2010'
HTML is sone component of that (and continually evolves). CSS is another (and continuously evolves)
jgraham: yeah, I've kind of figured that empirically along the way
but it's just kind of weird to have multiple versions of HTML, CSS, ECMAScript, etc.
but they all converge in one unifying concept
of *** HTML5 ***
haha
it just seems very atypical of the whole process
danbeam: It is, of course, insane
But marketing never seems to be about rationality
(and possibly hurtful, as now more people must agree to things to move forward, though I guess specs always have open requests for comments open to anybody)

hsivonen, cheers - and just the person, I had a question for you too :) would you say Harry's comments here are a fair sumamry wrt xmlns http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-lod/2011Jan/0213.html ?
his first paragraph that is
it is true that one thing that makes Namespaces annoying is that each identifier is a pair of strings instead of one string
and it is true that RDF identifiers are single strings
but prefix-based indirection in RDF flavors still shares other flaws with Namespaces
so you can't just concatenate the two strings and declare all problems of Namespaces solved

ack I wasn't planning to get in to that one, and it wasn't why i was asking either, was trying to figure out the problems with xmlns heritage itself, especially in regards to concatenating the two parts together (I couldn't find it defined in the related spec!)
ty for feedback though :)
Argh, I don't understand why it's so hard to give a simple listing of a script's alphabet, for use as list markers.
Of the very first script listed here, they have 58 characters listed (5 of them combining characters), and 53 codepoints listed.
And it's not what you think, where they just omitted the combiners.  Instead, they omitted four of the normal characters and *one* of the combiners.
I just read the blog post on no longer using version numbers for HTML. I understand why it's been done, but I cannot shake the feeling this is *very* bad for documentation.
Nah, you've still got the ability to refer to versions.  Just use the "Last Updated" date.
If you tried to document "HTML5" a few months ago, your documentation is already out of date.

Say an API is considered final, but two years later undergoes changes to make it better. Conceptually, this would mean two different versions two me. Perhaps browsers will only support one version (preferably the latest), but conceptually the two remain different two me
"Last Updated" is a very, very relative concept
I don't understand what's relative about a date.
*two me -> for to me
Ah, the date, my bad

Are there any guidelines for how frequently to update the standard? Because it'll be harder to track changes if they are made more than once a year. The dates are different, yes, but imagine response like "Oh, wait, there have been how many updates this year?"
The standard is updated continuously and as necessary.
In practice, that means a few updates a day right now.
I must note I'm a fan of development cycles (development -> alpha/beta/rc -> final)
During development most people know things can still change and that it's not wise to write tonnes of docs precisely because of that
Unfortunately, this is the web.  Something only becomes "final" when it's obsolete.
I'm thinking yearly cycles here
However, individual sections of the spec become stable as implementations appear.
I'm just 'worried' it'll become hard to keep up
It won't be any harder than it has been for the past 5 years that the spec has been developing.  ^_^
IMHO versions are not there to mark things as final, but to help people keep up
TabAtkins: True, but that's the idea of a development phase
The problem is that the subset of things that are stable enough to shapshot is very arbitrary, based entirely on whether several browsers have implemented it or not.
In my experience releases are great ways to push forward, because 90% of all people are not going to use something that's still in development anyway, because things are going too fast for them.
THen agian, my experience does not extend to writing web standards, so I may be entirely wrong here
Xano: It rarely matters what the spec says. It matters what's supported. So, may I suggest: http://caniuse.com/
The spec itself tracks whether features have been implemented, and there are other sites on the web that do similar things.
The spec helps to guide implementors and developers when using the features--not so much in deciding which features to use.

HTML4 was stable for a decade but that didn't mean you could trust browsers to have complete correct support for everything it defines - you still had to figure out exactly what features worked in which browsers, and avoid the ones that weren't well supported
I basically know the philosophy behind HTML(5). Is is truly about paving the cowpaths, or does it also help define how things should be best implemented?
Both.
so HTML(5) being a moving target doesn't change that
The spec defines things so browsers can work in the same direction.  Browsers implement things, so the spec has to match them if it wants to accurately describe reality.
FOr end users it's important to know when and how things are implemented consistently by browser makers, so they can use them
But if those implementations are still under development, they're not very useful for most end users, I guess.
Yup, and that has never been accurately communicated by having a "final version" or even a "snapshot".  It's always been communicated by community knowledge.
I guess it's just a matter of the lesser of two evils, right?
Like Philip said, HTML4 was stable and final for a decade, but you still can't use it to determine what's usable.
Well, most useful of the two evils.
It's not good for documentation, but that's just how things go
TabAtkins: fair enough
It seems at least some of the confusion stems from what zcorpan tweeted earlier today. People do not realize HTML never had versioning.
Or that we never implemented HTML4 for that matter...
The action that a browser takes if you drop a file into a page that doesn't have any dropzones is undefined, right?
Normally browsers just try to load the file as if you'd navigated to it as a file: url.
It probably is defined actually.
Because we had file drag & drop before dropzones.
I suspect that what you suggest might be the default action in some browsers, but you can override that from script.
Right; the default action is just what I'm talking about.  That part's UA-defined, right?
We're thinking of changing our behavior if you drag a file into a page that has dropzones, but drop it onto something that's not a dropzone.  We'd like to just ignore the drop in this circumstance.
Pretty sure that must be UA-defined
This would help, for example, people using GMail, if they're a little inaccurate and miss dropping the file into a message.

Rik`: That... that doesn't even make sense.
Nesting is just syntax sugar for not nesting.
foo { & bar { prop:value; } & baz { prop: value; }} === foo bar { prop: value; } foo baz { prop: value; }
that felt weird at the time but we haven't got the opportunity to discuss it more than 30 seconds so :)
Now, if you do the syntax wrong, it is indeed bad, because you need lots of lookahead.
But we're not making that mistake.

http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/FAQ updated based on theblog comments
TabAtkins, what are the fundamental differences?
Steve^: So far the biggest diff is some parser constraints and things have be kept declarative instead of sass's more imperative style.
Steve^: Vars act like they should in a declarative language, unlike SASS where it can be assigned different values at different times.
Then just some relatively minor syntax differences.
TabAtkins: Lots of people are worried about nesting as a perf drag because descendent selectors are slow
Less has constants, rather than variables
chriseppstein: Nesting has no inherent relationship to descendant selectors.  That's one of the things our syntax helps with.
TabAtkins: how so
foo { & > bar { prop: value; }} === foo > bar { prop: value; }
right. you can do that in sass
you can even omit the &
exactly
So how does the & help us?
Yeah, so there's no perf hit that you wouldn't see otherwise.  You're not forced to use descendant selectors.  It's exactly as easy to write performant nested CSS as not.
Steve^: body.foo &
Steve^: When parsing CSS, if you don't have an explicit indication that "here there be nesting", you ahve to have lots of lookahead.
In "foo { bar:hover a a a a a a { prop: value; }}", you don't know whether this is an element with a pseudoclass or a property named "bar" until you reach the {.
hmm, not so sure about that
ok, but does that matter?
Yes.  We try to minimize lookahead in CSS.
TabAtkins: I agree. It's just a concern that people have. might want to make sure to note it in your post
Except for a few minor places, we only have to do 1-token lookahead max.
chriseppstein: Sure.
Yea, nice to explain that. First glance it looks like less/sass but with more syntax
TabAtkins, how would you nest a :hover?
foo { &:hover { prop:value; }}
(This is another benefit of our syntax over the no-explicit-indicator syntax.)
Would you have mixins?
You can use mixins and nesting together, yeah.

I don't know.  The behavior of current-draft flexbox feels dangerously underspecified, so I'm not certain what behavior is right and what is wrong.

However!  I suspect the problem is that only display:block element can actually be flexbox children.  display:inline elements get wrapped in an anonymous block box.  This can cause troubles similar to what you get with the table-* display values sometimes.
How are Chrome going to get around the version numbering problem that Opera 10 found?

From the docs: "If inline-level elements are nested inside boxes, they get wrapped in an anonymous block which then takes part in the box layout." Wouldn't this mean that inline elements should behave exactly the same as block-level?

No, the thing that participates in layout is the block box, which you can't target or give any instructions to.
davidmurdoch_: In particular, you can't tell it to flex.

Yeah, anonymous blocks confuse a lot of people.
They are an unfortunate necessity in many circumstances.
